story:
IMPORTANT: this is an "all-or-nothing" campaign!
(please read IndieGoGo's "Fixed-Funding" topic for details)

The APE stands for "The Asset Pipeline Editor" created by Pedro Güida -a former MSFT XNA/DX MVP.

(i) Some of its key features:

  • It is a highly-customizable tool,
  • It eases the task of managing game content throughout the whole development process,
  • It helps you build asset files and processes for the platforms you desire, tailoring them for each platform,
  • It is a perfect choice not only for solo devs but also for teams, and
  • Its GUI is independent from any programming IDE!!!

(ii) Build your own import process, the one you dream of, with C# ...

Are you programming your games with C++, Objective-C, C#, Java, Phyton ... <pick your language here> ... and you need a content pipeline? Not using authorware like Unity3D, UDK, CryEngine or others? Have your own game engine? Then the APE will help you (and your team) manage your game assets with ease!

Use the well-known developer-friendly C# language to implement the software elements that will drive the behavior of the APE for your game-dev process.

Good question. 

(i) The answers ...

  • Microsoft decided not to continue developing the XNA Framwork any further,
  • Many alternatives do not come bundled with a handy content pipeline tool,
  • XNA's CP only runs on Windows machines since it uses the MSBuild API,
  • XNA's CP GUI has not been updated to work with the latest versions of the Visual Studio IDE,
  • Can you use the XNA's CP from within VS 2012 or VS 2013? Nope ...,
  • Why non-programmers should use any programming IDE as a CP in the first place?
  • XNA's CP only produces binaries targetting Microsoft's platforms.

(ii) Think of the APE as a replacement of XNA's content pipeline "in spirit" since ...

  • ... it does not strictly work the same way as XNA's CP did, ...
  • ... it does not come bundled with content importers for your game assets, ...
  • ... but it could have some importers if the extended goals are reached (wink!).

The way the APE works can be described in three words: Simple. Elegant. Handy.

(i) Basically, you ...:
  • ... create a new APE's solution and add projects per platform ...
  • ... add custom containers per project (and or use the ones provided by default) ...
  • ... add folders and raw files (being the latter the content) to each container ...
  • ... customize the input/output options per file (which could vary per platform) ...
  • ... indicate how the nodes in the solution tree must be built and copied, then ...
  • ... press the 'Build' button for the whole solution or one selected project ... 

(ii) ... and then, the APE will ...

  • ... convert each raw file into a content file for your specific game ...
  • ... copy the files to the output folders you specify, if applicable ... 
  • ... and presto! That is it!


Again: Simple! Elegant! Handy!

(iii) Take a peek at the APE's key logic elements:

  • AssetData: it defines the structure of a game asset. Some of you may refer to it as a DOM.
  • Importers: in charge of directing the whole process of converting the input (raw files) into output (the asset files for your game).
  • Processors: in charge of processing the input files in order to get a concrete asset data. A great power at your finger tips ... and "with great power ...".
  • Formatters: in charge of giving a structure to the output file. Add your own headers. Decide the type of serialization format you want to apply.  
  • Writers: in charge of packing and writing the output file as you define. Want to add metadata? How about some compression tasks of asset data? And protection? Yes! Now you can.
  • Packagers: in charge of packaging the output structure (that is, asset files and parent folders) of each project into one or several compressed files. You define what, how and where.

The APE gives you full control over the build process of content file ... it is in fact your build process!

So, create your key logic elements, add them to the editor as plug-in dynamic libraries, and start feeling the magic!

(iv) How about testing?

Yes! The APE comes with an assembly designed for testing purposes. 

  • Add break points, 
  • Debug offending code, 
  • Step through the whole source code until the import/write units are ready to go!

A time-saving feature ... 

  • ... no more witchcraft to debug importers ...
  • ... period.

(v) Anything else?

Yes! In addition to all these elements, the APE defines one more key element: Previewers ...

  • ... they help you define how to handle the preview of file types,
  • ... think of them as a general-purpose WIC-kindof element.

The APE comes with a few previewers for common business-friendly license formats (only for Windows at the current stage), but ...:

  • ... you can create your own as plug-in dynamic libraries for the editor,
  • ... and even replace the default previewers that come with it!

Last but not least, the APE has a command-line tool called "APEBuild":

This tool can be used, for instance, to automate batch builds on a server-side environment. Yes, commit source and solution/project files, execute the tool, and return when the build is done. Great!

The APE is on alpha stage for the Windows OS platform.

(i) So ...

  • ... it is not yet ready for a public release,
  • ... it is functional for in-house projects, 
  • ... there are some features left to add ...
  • ... plus some more testing to do.

(ii) Right now, out of the box for non-inhouse purposes ... 

... the tool has no other import unit than the pass-through one, and
... the tool can be therefore used as content organizer, only.

(iii) ... that is of course ...

... unless individual extended goals are reached in this campaign.

Remember that you can create your own import units.

(iv) In case you may be wondering it, 

... if this campaign fails the APE there is no intention of public the APE
... so, in that case, it will remain private for in-house productions, only.

The main goal of this campaign is to push the APE to its first release version, as a commercial solution for the Window OS platforms supported by the .NET Framework v4.5 (check system requierements here). 

(i) Some of the remaining tasks to achieve this goal:

  • Replace some third-party APIs with commercial solutions,
  • Clean up some source code and comment operations,
  • Documentation (sigh! Always a bummer ...),
  • Coding samples (for you to reference).
  • Build a "pro" website for the product.
  • Add a few more (needed) features.
  • More testing (public testing).
  • Others (licenses, etc.).

(ii) Regarding each license of the APE's first release version ...

  • ... the price of each license will be $100 USD per seat per platform,
  • ... you can get at least one license depending on your contribution to this campaing,
  • ... the minimum contribution to get one license is $30 USD. A bargain!

So take a moment to read carefully the available perks for your kind contributions (to get licenses and even early access to the product).

(iii) A few notes regarding this goal and extended goals:

  • All the goals in this campaign conform the phase 1 in the APE's roadmap,
  • All import units developed for each extended goal that gets reached will be released as open source,
  • For extended goals #1 to #3, the XNB file format documentation will be followed.
  • Unless goal #4 is reached on the campaign, import/write units created on extended goals from #1 upto #3 will not have LZX compression,
  • Solutions -currently found- for each extended goal may change by the time development starts, and
  • Content types not mentioned in any of the extended goals will not be provided in this campaign.

Puzzled? Please read these posts for an in-depth explanation ...

The first set of extended goals aims to the creation of standard 2D games, and by "standard" I mean, without the use of shaders.

(i) 2D Textures

Based on the surface formats supported by the last version of the XNA Framework, the following output will be available:

  • Colour (standard 32-bit RGBA texture),
  • Compressed (yes! DXT 1 and 5 compression),
  • Unchanged (for supported surface formats).

Plus some other features like mip-map generation  ... stay tuned for videos explaining them.

(B) Fonts

The APE's equivalents for XNA's font processors:

  • Font textures (supporting the same format used by the XNA Framework), and 
  • Font descriptors (yes! Font textures will be created according to the description).

The second set of extended goals aims to build SoundEffect, Song and Video content files.

(A) Sound Effects

The output file will be an uncompressed PCM sound effect, where you will be able to select its quality as per Monogame's specs: 

  • "Best" (source sample rate), 
  • "Medium" (3/4 of the source sample rate),
  •  "Low" (1/2 of the source sample rate).

(B) Songs

XNA's Content Pipeline does not bundle audio bits with the ".xnb" binary file. In fact, it generates a tiny file that embeds the relative path to the audio file to load and play (and its duration).

(i) So ... ?

  • Encoding for the WAV audio fomat will be provided,
  • Encoding for the Ogg/Vorbis audio format may or may not be provided,
  • MP3 encoding/decoding will NOT be provided due to its restrictive licensing model,
  • Encoding for WMA and XMA/XMA2 audio formats will NOT be provided.

(ii) Therefore ...? 

  • You can always get the format that you need in an external audio editor
  • Use the pass-through processor to create the corresponding binary file for it.

(C) Videos

Just like with the Song content, XNA creates a binary file with the relative path to the WMV file and some additional data, like, among others, duration and size (width and height).

(i) So ... ?

  • The processor will just copy the source video without any modification to it.
  • You wil be able to provide other formats than WMV ones, in case you need it.

(ii) Therefore ...? 

  • You can always get the format that you need in an external audio editor
  • Use the pass-through processor to create the corresponding binary file for it.

The third set of extended goals aims to build some of the content types used for 3D games, like volume textures, cube texture, 3D models and custom effects.

(A) 3D/Cube Textures

As a corolary of the extended goal #1, there are a couple of texture types supported by the XNA Framework (and Monogame): 3D textures and Cube textures ...

  • ... import volume and cube textures directly (yes! DDS ones), and ...
  • ... create these type of textures directly from the APE it-self.

And yes! With mip-mapping.

(B) 3D Models

You know the drill ...

  • Bones, 
  • Transforms, 
  • Model Meshes,
  • Model mesh parts, 
  • Bounding spheres, 
  • Vertex declarations, 
  • Vertex and index buffers,
  • ... and so on so forth.

The whole standard bunch. There is a lot to do and test here!

(C) Custom Shaders

The icing on the cake!

You provide the proper compiled shader object for the target platform (not source files), and the APE will take that object (say, a ".cso" file) and generate the corresponding binary file (".xnb").

Yes! You will be able to set different binary shaders (that is to say, files with compiled byte-code) under the same asset name on a platform basis targeting either DX or OpenGL and its versions.

Even though by using the APE you could change the code of import/write units your-selves to compress asset data with any of the compression techniques supported by the .NET Framework 4.5, and Monogame's source code could get modified to support such techniques (ditto for other solutions -like WaveEngine and such- or your own game engine), the goal here is to develop a LZX compressor with C# (following Microsoft's documentation) and integrate it with the import/write units developed for goals #1 to #3.

A difficult task, with lots of trying and error, but with patience, hard work and your support it could get done. Let's go for it!

    Now, about monetary contributions ...

    For those of you willing to contribute with some cash to this campaign, basically ...:

    • ... for $10 USD you will have my gratitude, only,
    • ... for $30 USD, you will get one license of the APE v1.x_final (when released),
    • ... after that entry point, depending on your contribution you could get more licenses, early access to the bits and even a special mention on the credits,
    • ... licenses are per seat per platform so each license is assigned to one seat for a specific platform,
    • ... all licenses are valid for the first release version of the APE unless indicated in the corresponding perk (they could last more), and
    • ... contributors (excluding "Casual Backers") will always get special upgrade prices.

    Please take a few minutes to check the perks. 

    Before making any contribution to this (or any) campaign, it is important that you carefully (read and) assess all its risks as well as the moral/technical solvency of the campaign's owner.

    Basically, regarding the risks, please be aware that ...

    • ... some of the technologies to be used to achieve -mainly- the extended goals may change its licensing to non-business-friendly ones, forcing the dev to look for alternatives,
    • ... extended goals, if reached, could remain uncompleted for a time period that exceeds expectations,
    • ... some of the goals could get never achieved due to reasons (technical, legal or else) beyond dev's power, 
    • ... dev costs for the project as a whole or in part may have been miscalculated, generating a risk of roadmap truncation.

    Regarding the dev, as many of you may already know, inter alia:

    • Pedro was an MVP for the techs of XNA and DirectX,
    • He reviewed books (and even one video course) about XNA,
    • He was a mod in the "Create" forums (even though I was not one of the most active mods),
    • He used to write about the XNA Framework and what not wherever he could (like in his blog, for instance),
    • He was finalist in a couple of contests (local and international) on 2008 (where he used the XNA Framework for his entries), and last but not least
    • He still knows the XNA Framework by heart (he is an expert), being this point, one of the most relevant ones for this campaign.

    Rest assured, even though that -like in any investment/contribution- there are usually no guarantees, that Pedro will do his best to mitigate all of the above-mentioned risks.

    So let us hope you decide to contribute to this campaign.

    In case you cannot afford a monetary contribution, you can help by:

    • Using IndieGoGo's share tools,
    • Generating buzz about this campaign among your contacts, and
    • Providing me with commercial-friendly licenses in case you believe your products could boost the development of the APE and or the APE it-self!
    • Taking to TPTB that you may know at companies that develop products that I might use to achieve this campaign's goals so as to convince them to contribute as indicated in the previous bullet.

    The Asset Pipeline Editor (or "the APE") is an outstanding tool to manage content files and create your own build process. 

    It is independent of any programming IDE and if this campaign succeeds, and after completing development for all the goals eventually reached in this campaign, phase 2 could then begin in order to port it to MacOsX and Linux platforms (but not as part of this campaign). Yes, phase 1 here targets Windows OS platform and phase 2 porting it with the help of Xamarin.Mac for MacOsX and GTK# for Linux OS. Multiplatform support is coming your way ...

    You will witness soon that the APE is indeed worth every cent/penny you may contribute here.

    In short, a must have!

    Thanks guys for reading and in advance for your support/contributions!!!

    [Please read more about this campaing -and each of its goals- here.]

some more testing to do.

(ii)
Right
now, out of the box for non-inhouse purposes ... 
... the
tool
has no other import unit than the pass-through one, and...
the
tool can
be therefore used as content organizer, only.
(iii) ... that is of course ...
...
unless individual extended goals are reached in this campaign.
Remember that you can create your own import units.
(iv) In
case
you may be wondering it, 
...
if this campaign fails the APE there is no intention of public
the APE...
so,
in
that case, it will remain private for in-house productions,
only.





The main
goal of this campaign is
to push the
APE
to
its first release version,
as a commercial solution for the Window OS platforms
supported by the .NET Framework v4.5 (check
system requierements here). 
(i) Some of
the remaining tasks to
achieve
this goal:


Replace
some
third-party APIs with commercial solutions,


Clean up some source code and comment operations,


Documentation (sigh! Always a bummer ...),


Coding
samples (for
you to reference).


Build a "pro" website for the product.

Add a
few more (needed) features.

More testing
(public testing).


Others (licenses, etc.).


(ii) Regarding each
license of the APE's first release
version
...


...
the
price of each
license will be $100 USD per seat per platform,


...
you
can
get at least one license depending on your contribution to this
campaing,


...
          the
minimum contribution to get one license is $30 USD. A bargain!


So take
a
moment to read carefully the available perks for your kind
contributions (to get licenses and even early access to the product).
(iii) A few notes
regarding this goal and extended goals:

All
the goals in this campaign conform the phase 1
in the APE's roadmap,

All
import
units developed for each extended goal that gets reached will be
released as open source,

For extended goals #1 to #3, the XNB file format documentation will be followed.

Unless
goal #4 is reached on the campaign, import/write units created on extended goals from
#1 upto #3 will
not have LZX compression,


Solutions -currently
found- for
each extended goal may change by the time development starts, and

Content
types not mentioned in any of the extended goals will not be provided
in
this campaign.

Puzzled? Please read these posts for an in-depth
explanation
...



The first set of extended goals aims to the creation of
standard 2D games, and by "standard" I mean, without the use of shaders.
(i) 2D
Textures
Based on the surface formats supported by the last
version
of
the XNA Framework, the following output will be available:


Colour
(standard 32-bit RGBA texture),


Compressed
(yes! DXT 1 and 5 compression),


Unchanged
(for supported surface formats).


Plus some other features like mip-map generation
 ...
stay tuned for videos explaining them.
(B) Fonts
The APE's equivalents for XNA's font processors:


Font
textures (supporting the same format used by the XNA Framework),
and 

Font
descriptors (yes! Font textures will be created according to the
description).



The second set of extended goals aims to build
SoundEffect,
Song and Video content files.
(A) Sound Effects
The output file will be an uncompressed PCM sound
effect,
where you will be able to select its quality as per Monogame's
specs: 


"Best"
(source sample rate), 


"Medium"
(3/4 of the source sample rate),


 "Low"
(1/2 of the source sample rate).


(B) Songs
XNA's Content Pipeline does not bundle audio
bits
with the ".xnb" binary file. In fact, it generates a tiny
file that embeds the relative path to the audio file to load and play
(and its duration).
(i) So ... ?


Encoding
for the WAV audio fomat will be provided,


Encoding
for the Ogg/Vorbis audio format may or may not be provided,


MP3 encoding/decoding will NOT
be provided due to its restrictive licensing model,


Encoding
for WMA and XMA/XMA2 audio formats will NOT be provided.


(ii) Therefore ...? 


You
can
always get the format that you need in an external audio editor


Use
the
pass-through processor to create the corresponding binary file for it.


(C) Videos
Just like with the Song content, XNA creates a
binary
file with the relative path to the WMV file and some additional data,
like, among others, duration and size (width and height).
(i) So ...
?


The
processor will just copy the source video without any modification to
it.


You
wil
be
able to provide other formats than WMV ones, in case you need it.


(ii) Therefore ...? 

You can always get the format that you need in an
external
audio editor
Use
the
pass-through processor to create the corresponding binary file for it.



The third set of extended goals aims to build some of
the
content types used for 3D games, like volume textures, cube texture, 3D
models and custom effects.
(A) 3D/Cube Textures
As a corolary of the extended goal #1, there are a
couple of
texture types supported by the XNA Framework (and Monogame): 3D
textures and Cube textures ...


...
import
volume and cube textures directly (yes! DDS ones), and ...

...
create
these type of textures directly from the APE it-self.

And yes! With mip-mapping.
(B) 3D Models
You
know the drill ...


Bones, 


Transforms, 


Model
Meshes,


Model
mesh
parts, 


Bounding
spheres, 


Vertex
declarations, 


Vertex
and
index buffers,

... and so on so forth.
        

The
whole
standard
bunch. There is a lot to do and test here!
(C) Custom Shaders
The icing on the cake!
You
provide
the proper compiled shader object for the target platform (not source
files), and the
APE
will take that object (say, a ".cso" file) and generate the
corresponding binary file (".xnb").
Yes! You will be able to set different binary shaders
(that is to say, files with compiled byte-code) under the same asset name on a
platform basis targeting either DX or
OpenGL and its versions.



Even
though by using the APE you could change the code of import/write units
your-selves to compress asset data with any of the compression techniques
supported by the .NET Framework 4.5, and Monogame's source code could
get modified to support such techniques (ditto for other solutions -like WaveEngine and such- or your own game engine), the goal here is to develop a
LZX compressor with C#
(following
      Microsoft's documentation) and integrate it with the import/write units developed for goals #1 to #3.
A difficult task, with lots of trying
and error, but with patience, hard work and your support it could get
done. Let's go for it!




Now, about monetary contributions ...
For those of you willing to contribute with some cash to
this
campaign, basically ...:


...
for
$10
USD you will have my gratitude, only,


...
for
$30 USD, you will get one license of the APE v1.x_final
(when
released),


...
          after
that entry point, depending on your contribution you could
get more
licenses, early access to the bits and even a special mention on the credits,


... licenses are per seat per platform so each license is assigned to one seat for a specific platform,

... all licenses are valid for the first release version of the APE unless indicated in the corresponding perk (they could last more), and
... contributors (excluding "Casual Backers") will always get special upgrade prices.

Please
take a few minutes to check
the perks. 
Before making any contribution to this (or any)
campaign, it is important that you carefully (read and) assess all its
risks as well as the moral/technical solvency of the campaign's owner.
Basically, regarding the risks,
please be aware that ...


...
some of the technologies to be used to achieve -mainly- the extended
goals may change its licensing to
non-business-friendly ones, forcing the dev to look for alternatives,

... extended goals, if reached, could remain
uncompleted
for a time period that exceeds expectations,
... some of the goals could get never
achieved due to reasons (technical, legal or else) beyond
dev's power, 
... dev costs for the project as a whole or in part
may have been miscalculated, generating a risk of roadmap truncation.

Regarding
      the dev, as many
of you may already know, inter
alia:

Pedro was an MVP for the techs of XNA and DirectX, 
He reviewed books (and even one video course)
about XNA, 
He was a mod in the "Create" forums (even though I
was
not one of the most active mods),
He used to write about
the XNA Framework and what not wherever he could (like in his blog,
for instance),
He was finalist in a couple of contests (local and
international) on 2008 (where he used the XNA Framework for his
entries), and last but not least
He still knows the XNA Framework by heart (he is an
expert), being this
point, one of the most relevant ones for this campaign.

Rest assured, even though that -like in any
investment/contribution- there are usually no guarantees, that Pedro
will do his best to mitigate all of the above-mentioned risks.
So let us hope you decide
to contribute to this campaign.

In case you cannot afford a monetary contribution, you
can
help by:

Using IndieGoGo's share tools,

Generating buzz about this
campaign
among your contacts, and

Providing me with commercial-friendly
licenses
in case you believe your products could boost the development of the
APE and or the APE it-self!

Taking to TPTB that you may know at
companies that develop products that I might use to achieve
this campaign's goals so as to convince them to contribute as indicated
in the previous bullet.


The
Asset
Pipeline Editor (or "the APE") is an outstanding tool to manage content
files and create your own build process. 
It is
      independent
of
any programming IDE
and if this campaign succeeds, and after completing development for all
the goals eventually reached in this campaign, phase 2 could then begin in order to
port it to MacOsX and Linux platforms (but not as part of this campaign). Yes, phase 1 here targets
Windows OS platform and phase 2 porting it with the help of Xamarin.Mac
for MacOsX and GTK# for Linux OS. Multiplatform support is coming your
way ...
You
will
witness soon that the
APE is indeed worth every cent/penny you may
contribute here.
In short, a must have!
Thanks guys
for reading and in advance for
your
support/contributions!!!

[Please read
more about this campaing -and each of its
goals- here.]

story:
Medieval Madness

Medieval Madness is a real-time strategy board game for two players where strategy and speed are equally important. The game is set in Medieval Times and it tells the story of two kings who fight out their age-old conflict in a final battle.

The game is in real-time, so there is no taking turns. All the actions and units of the game are displayed on coins. By drawing coins from a pouch the player can make his units take different actions. Units can attack, move, defend and barricade. A player is only allowed to hold one coin at a time, so it must either be used or discarded directly before drawing another. The goal of the game is to defeat all enemy units.

We think Medieval Madness will appeal to the board game fanatic. The game is really easy to learn but is hard to master. Even though the rules are simple, the possibilities are endless. After lots of testing we still encounter different situations and come up with new strategies. The game is therefore very competitive and replayable. The game is short, but intense, because an average game takes 10 minutes. A great game when you have a few minutes to spare.

Our goal

Our goal is to get a total of $13.000. Although this might seem like a lot, it is the minimum amount of money that we need to print and produce the game and ship it to you. To print the game at a professional company we need to order a minimum of 1000 units. Combined with shipping costs to Europe and the rest of the world we need the 13.000 to at least break even. We are not looking for a huge profit, our first and main goal is to get our game on the market, for others to enjoy.

If we exceed the $13.000 mark we can use that profit to further promote and sell our game. We have also started developing a tablet version of the game (IOS/Android), and some extra resources can also help this project. We really believe Medieval Madness is a great game and that it can be a success. The game is fully designed and tested, all we need to do is print and publish the game, something that we cannot do without your donations!

The Game

For a more detailed explanation of the game, you can take a look at the instruction manual.

About Us

We´re both game designers and just graduated from the Utrecht School of the Arts in Game Design & Development. For more information or our work, check our portfolio's: Emiel Bransen and Christiaan Ribbens. Peter Klijn  created the artwork and illustrations for the playfield and box.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every donation is welcome, but you can also help by spreading the word! Share this campaign on social media and tell your friends, if you can get more people interested in this project we have a higher chance of reaching our goal! 

Extra info perks

Print and play

The print and play version of the game features the playfield (A3), the coins (A4, can be best printed on a label), and the instruction manual. You could use something like cardboard to make your own coins.

Shipping costs

The price for the game is $25. The shipping costs are $10 for Europe and $20 for worldwide. The shipping costs are included in the perks. If you want multiple copies please use the multiple copies perk for your region, you will only have to pay the shipping costs once. For example: you would like to buy 3 copies and you live in Europe. You will have to pay: 3 X $25 + $10 = $85.

Be a king / queen

If you claim one of the two 'Be a king / queen' perks, you can choose the name of one of the kings / queens. It does not necessarily have to be your name, you can also choose one. We do have some restrictions on what the name can be. It has to at least sound like a name or a title (something like ‘the conqueror'). It cannot be a nickname like xDoomslayer4000 since it does not sound like an actual name. Of course, no strong language and other dirty words allowed.

The name is used in the premise of the game, you can read it in the instruction manual. The names that are used now are 'Christofer' and 'Emielius'. The premise will also be featured on the back of the box.

story: Hi, I am James from Js Studios Games and I am teaming up with peachy dev from NA Games to make a hack and slash platformer with a strong story to sell and help support our studios. We will be creating a heroic tale of a lonely knight who's past has damned him to better his world and rid the world of the corrupt evil. This game will have varying mechanics, to aid your mission and different ways to play it it will be a 2D platformer with a hack and slash game aspects and interesting story. We need your help to pay for Adobe licenses and for marketing/ advertisement. No one will know about our game if we can't get it out there for people to see and all of our hard work would be wasted. That's where you come in, you will help us pay for the advertisement which is very necessary. If you support our game, you will get the game free of charge and with a special code, get bonus content. You will also see behind the scenes on everything that we are working on and we will make sure to always keep you posted with pictures and videos. I hope to reach our marketing goal of $1,000 and maybe even surpass that goal, but any money that you all give will be very helpful. We really need this game to sell to help both of our studios going and if our game doesn't get noticed, it won't sell. We have made other separate small web projects before and I think we are ready now to make a good, selling game if we team up. We met up over Discord and he was an artist and I was a programmer and we made a small web game and became good friends. Then he brought me a big project idea and asked if I wanted to help out on it. I thought that it was a great idea and I got to work. Now we realize that we should get support to help this project that we plan to take a year and a half, actually be seen and make us some money. One challenge that we will face is we both have real lives outside of game development that might take up game development time, but we won't let that affect us too much as we have had practice working around it. We also aren't musicians or foley artist but I think that we can get help from other people on his Discord server. Now if you can't support us and even if you are or can, please get out there and tell people about our campaign. Also, don't forget the Indiegogo sharing. Thanks, and please help support our campaign.

story:
Guardians of Noterra is a persistant online multiplayer hybrid between Action RPGs and Monster Taming genre games.  

Pre-Alpha prototype presentation;


Planned Features

Guardians!  Over 100 different creatures to discover and befriend - each with different strategic gameplay mechanics.

Elements!  Over a dozen different elements with different strengths and weaknesses.  Fully customize your strategy!

Heroic Character!  Player characters doesn't just sit back and give orders to their Guardians - they have combat abilities as well, and can join in the fight!

Real Time!  No turned based system - Players and Guardians have Action Points that regenerate at a fixed pace, allowing you to activate abilities as you need them - you can even save your action points to perform a combination of moves back to back.

Region-based Gameplay!  Two different regions at launch - each with a different distribution of Guardians and elemental types.  Each region has their own economy and Tournament metagame.

Player Economy!  Guardians of Noterra will have an in-game supply and demand economy, gathering and crafting systems.  Train your Guardians to collect and manufacture resources!

Genetic Traits!  Guardians have traits determined by genetic markers.  Crossbreed your Guardians to select the perfect traits for your Guardians.

Mythology!  Much of the world is based on real world mythology (with creative licence.)  Explore the myths of Eastern Europe and Mesoamerica!


Guardians

Standard Guardians in the video - listed by order of appearance;

These images are not the final release, they are place holder graphics.  If we meet our funding goals then artists will be hired to polish these designs for final release.

 Dinomite
Primary:  Primal, Toxic, Earth

Dreamkeeper Worm

Primary:  Nature, Æther

Dreamkeeper Moth

Primary:  Nature, Æther


Highland Youth

Primary:  Primal

Secondary:  Martial

Aven Lad

Primary:  Wind, Primal or Martial

Timber Pup

Primary:  Primal

Nimbusite

Primary:  Nature

Secondary:  Varies (by form)

Naga

Primary:  Toxic, Earth

Gorgon

Primary: Toxic, Earth

Rimefire Witch

Primary:  Ice, Æther

Secondary:  Spirit

Ember Sprout

Primary:  Fire, Plant

Secondary:  Nature

Monolith

Primary:  Stone, Mystic

Secondary:  Varies (by core)

Quickling Warmage

Primary:  Lightning, Martial
Lyrist

Primary:  Tone, Martial

Battle Rager

Primary:  Primal, Chakra

Monolith

Primary:  Stone

Secondary:  Varies (by core)


Perk Explanations

Membership Benefits;

Guardians of Noterra is free to play, however purchasing a premium membership gives several advantages.  Several Indiegogo perks grant bonus membership time.  This time starts when the game goes live (all players are considered members during the Alpha phase)

These memberships are done via Member Tickets, which will be added to your account close to release.  These Member Tickets are fully tradeable in the Auction economy system, so you receive them even if you have a Lifetime Membership perk.

The benefits are;

  • Membership tag in chat.
  • +10% increase in Experience gained for you and your Guardians.
  • +15% increase in earning in-game currency.
  • +5% increase in item drops.
  • Guardians are more likely to ‘resonate’ with you, allowing you to befriend them.
  • Auction fees are halved.
  • Increased economy productivity (Guardian crafting/harvesting)
  • and more… to be determined.

Promotional Guardians!

There are a number of special Guardians available from the Platinum Supporter perk.  In each of the following cases, the Guardians will be exclusive to this promotion and unavailable to other players in any way until 2016.  This means that only participants of the Indigogo campaign will have access to these Guardians for a full year after the public launch date!  After this date, these Guardians may be available as high end tournament prizes or other promotions, but they will never again be offered with maximum stats as they are here


Frequently Asked Questions

What platform(s) will the game run on?

During the early Alpha stage, the game will be run only via the Unity Web Player, which is available to both Windows and Mac players.  Any computer compatible with this player can run the Alpha test through a browser window.

The game will initially launch for Windows and Mac downloadable clients as well.  Long term plans include Ouya and Linux platforms as well.

How will the money be used?

The money will primarily be used to pay developer salaries so that they can work full-time on this rather than having to have a secondary source of income.

Funds beyond that will be used to contract with artists and license music, as well as help pay for server upgrades.

What happens if you don't reach your goal?

Our developers will be living off of instant noodles for several months :(

Seriously though, this campaign is set to flexible funding mode.  We can produce this game on a shoestring budget if we absolutely have to.  This is because we can do most of the coding and art in house.  It will, however, take a lot longer to finish the project for launch, and the end result will not be as polished as it could be.

Meeting the goal allows us to outsource a lot of the work and hire better artistic talent and hire more developers to the team.   This will enable us to release the project much faster and it will be a better game overall!

Why Alpha test?

Most gamers are familiar with MMOs having a Beta phase where they seek out members of the gaming community to participate in a “closed” or “open” Beta.  A game in Beta phase is mostly finished – just a little bit of polish and a few bugs ironing out.  Most of the time, player feedback during this phase is ignored (unless it is a critical bug report)

A game in Alpha testing, however, is still exploring it’s mechanics and has room to grow.  Alpha tests are usually much smaller, which allows people in the test a direct line to the developer’s ear.  Because of these reasons, your feedback may actually shape how the game develops before it becomes closer to being finalized.  In addition, you get to watch a game as it progresses from infacy to a full-fledged game – which is a huge insight into how a game is made if you have an interest in working in the video game industry in the future.

That said, however, there are a lot more glitches and much of the art will be place-holders until it comes closer to a finished stage.

When do I receive my Perks?

The Basic Supporter and Copper Supporter packages will receive a coupon code via email when the game reaches Beta stage OR becomes open to the public during late Alpha (whichever happens first based on production needs).   The Basic and Copper Supporter perks do not include an Alpha testing key.For 

Silver Supporter and above – your Alpha test key will be emailed to you as soon as Alpha testing begins.  Our goal is to have the Alpha test ready to accept players within 40 days of campaign ending.  The first phase of the Alpha test will be open from Friday morning through Sunday night.  Once the client reaches a more stable version and does not require many updates, it will be open full-time.

All other perks will be handed out as the game reaches a stage where they are supported, and will be automatically credited to an account created with the Alpha test key.  (Premium currency, for example, isn’t used until the game gets closer to Beta and the Premium Store opens.)

What makes a Guardian ‘Common’, ‘Uncommon’, or ‘Rare’?

Guardians of Noterra uses a region-based system for Guardian distribution.  Guardians found in the country of Cailatia may be very different from those found in Hondaco.  In order to somewhat preserve the different metagames for each region, a rarity system is devised, indicating how hard they are to find and import into the region.Due to the plague spread by invading monsters, each region has differing import restrictions in order to avoid cross contamination.


Common:  Common Guardians are frequent in the region.  They can easily be found in the wild and it is trivial to import Guardians from the same family that appear in other regions.

Uncommon:  Uncommon Guardians appear infrequently in the region.  While they can be found in the wild, it is much less likely.  Importing Uncommon Guardians is not very difficult.

Rare:  The 'Rare' category covers Guardians that are not native to the region. They do not appear in the wild anywhere in the region and the import restrictions on Rare Guardians is quite steep.  Rare Guardians are not necessarily more powerful - it just means they cannot be found in that region normally.  A Guardian that is Rare to the Hondaco Region may be Common in the Cailatia region, and vice-versa.


The rarities play a part in Region-based tournament modes.  Participants in high level tournaments bring up to 5 Guardians to a battle, but at most 1 of these may be Rare.  This allows participants to master the metagame within a specific region with only a few 'wild cards'.  Worldwide events allow Guardians from all over the world and do not have this restriction.

Microtransactions?  You mean this game will be Pay-to-Win?

We despise games that are designed to be Pay-to-Win, and will be doing everything we can to avoid that outcome.  We plan to offer cosmetic and feature perks on the store that do not significantly affect gameplay.  We may offer Uncommon and Rare Guardians as well with the understanding that these Guardians are not necessarily more powerful than Common Guardians, just harder to get (and thus it is a time-saving feature).

Anything in the Cash Store that has a gameplay benefit will be obtainable in-game in some way - such as through Tournament prizes or promotional events.  Additionally, we plan to make the Cash Store currency tradeable so that players can exchange in-game currency for Cash Store currency.  Thus, all the features are available in some way, free to play.


A Message from the Lead Developer;

Hello, my name is Justin White. I am the Sole Proprietor of Aquamentos Games and the Lead Developer of Guardians of Noterra.  

I started this project because it was a game that I wanted to play. That’s the driving passion behind Aquamentos Games – to make games that I want to play, and that I think others would like to play too. This approach allows me to design games that are focused on gameplay – because that’s what I care about as a gamer. 

I’m not in this business for the money, I consider that a secondary concern. That said, designing and running online games costs money. The servers have to stay up, and having cash flow means more and better games in the future. For this reason, the game will be supported with microtransactions for in-game content. I hope that you will find the system that I intend to implement fair, without feeling like you are ‘forced’ to pay in order to enjoy the game, unlike many other games out there that use this “Freemium” (Free, with paid premiums) model.
story_txt:
Guardians of Noterra is a persistant online multiplayer hybrid between Action RPGs and Monster Taming genre games.  Pre-Alpha prototype presentation;


Planned Features
Guardians!  Over 100 different creatures to discover and befriend - each with different strategic gameplay mechanics.Elements!  Over a dozen different elements with different strengths and weaknesses.  Fully customize your strategy!Heroic Character!  Player characters doesn't just sit back and give orders to their Guardians - they have combat abilities as well, and can join in the fight!Real Time!  No turned based system - Players and Guardians have Action Points that regenerate at a fixed pace, allowing you to activate abilities as you need them - you can even save your action points to perform a combination of moves back to back.Region-based Gameplay!  Two different regions at launch - each with a different distribution of Guardians and elemental types.  Each region has their own economy and Tournament metagame.Player Economy!  Guardians of Noterra will have an in-game supply and demand economy, gathering and crafting systems.  Train your Guardians to collect and manufacture resources!Genetic Traits!  Guardians have traits determined by genetic markers.  Crossbreed your Guardians to select the perfect traits for your Guardians.Mythology!  Much of the world is based on real world mythology (with creative licence.)  Explore the myths of Eastern Europe and Mesoamerica!GuardiansStandard Guardians in the video - listed by order of appearance;These images are not the final release, they are place holder graphics.  If we meet our funding goals then artists will be hired to polish these designs for final release.







DinomitePrimary:  Primal, Toxic, Earth










Dreamkeeper WormPrimary:  Nature, Æther









Dreamkeeper MothPrimary:  Nature, Æther








Highland YouthPrimary:  Primal
Secondary:  Martial





Aven LadPrimary:  Wind, Primal or Martial





Timber PupPrimary:  Primal





NimbusitePrimary:  Nature
Secondary:  Varies (by form)





Naga
Primary:  Toxic, Earth

Gorgon

Primary: Toxic, Earth








Rimefire Witch
Primary:  Ice, Æther
Secondary:  Spirit








Ember SproutPrimary:  Fire, Plant
Secondary:  Nature





MonolithPrimary:  Stone, Mystic
Secondary:  Varies (by core)





Quickling WarmagePrimary:  Lightning, Martial







LyristPrimary:  Tone, Martial





Battle RagerPrimary:  Primal, Chakra





Monolith
Primary:  Stone
Secondary:  Varies (by core)



Perk ExplanationsMembership Benefits;Guardians of Noterra is free to play, however purchasing a premium membership gives several advantages.  Several Indiegogo perks grant bonus membership time.  This time starts when the game goes live (all players are considered members during the Alpha phase)These memberships are done via Member Tickets, which will be added to your account close to release.  These Member Tickets are fully tradeable in the Auction economy system, so you receive them even if you have a Lifetime Membership perk.The benefits are;
Membership tag in chat.
+10% increase in Experience gained for you and your Guardians.
+15% increase in earning in-game currency.
+5% increase in item drops.
Guardians are more likely to ‘resonate’ with you, allowing you to befriend them.
Auction fees are halved.
Increased economy productivity (Guardian crafting/harvesting)
and more… to be determined.
Promotional Guardians!There are a number of special Guardians available from the Platinum Supporter perk.  In each of the following cases, the Guardians will be exclusive to this promotion and unavailable to other players in any way until 2016.  This means that only participants of the Indigogo campaign will have access to these Guardians for a full year after the public launch date!  After this date, these Guardians may be available as high end tournament prizes or other promotions, but they will never again be offered with maximum stats as they are hereFrequently Asked QuestionsWhat platform(s) will the game run on?During the early Alpha stage, the game will be run only via the Unity Web Player, which is available to both Windows and Mac players.  Any computer compatible with this player can run the Alpha test through a browser window.The game will initially launch for Windows and Mac downloadable clients as well.  Long term plans include Ouya and Linux platforms as well.How will the money be used?The money will primarily be used to pay developer salaries so that they can work full-time on this rather than having to have a secondary source of income.Funds beyond that will be used to contract with artists and license music, as well as help pay for server upgrades.What happens if you don't reach your goal?Our developers will be living off of instant noodles for several months :(Seriously though, this campaign is set to flexible funding mode.  We can produce this game on a shoestring budget if we absolutely have to.  This is because we can do most of the coding and art in house.  It will, however, take a lot longer to finish the project for launch, and the end result will not be as polished as it could be.Meeting the goal allows us to outsource a lot of the work and hire better artistic talent and hire more developers to the team.   This will enable us to release the project much faster and it will be a better game overall!Why Alpha test?Most gamers are familiar with MMOs having a Beta phase where they seek out members of the gaming community to participate in a “closed” or “open” Beta.  A game in Beta phase is mostly finished – just a little bit of polish and a few bugs ironing out.  Most of the time, player feedback during this phase is ignored (unless it is a critical bug report)A game in Alpha testing, however, is still exploring it’s mechanics and has room to grow.  Alpha tests are usually much smaller, which allows people in the test a direct line to the developer’s ear.  Because of these reasons, your feedback may actually shape how the game develops before it becomes closer to being finalized.  In addition, you get to watch a game as it progresses from infacy to a full-fledged game – which is a huge insight into how a game is made if you have an interest in working in the video game industry in the future.That said, however, there are a lot more glitches and much of the art will be place-holders until it comes closer to a finished stage.When do I receive my Perks?The Basic Supporter and Copper Supporter packages will receive a coupon code via email when the game reaches Beta stage OR becomes open to the public during late Alpha (whichever happens first based on production needs).   The Basic and Copper Supporter perks do not include an Alpha testing key.For Silver Supporter and above – your Alpha test key will be emailed to you as soon as Alpha testing begins.  Our goal is to have the Alpha test ready to accept players within 40 days of campaign ending.  The first phase of the Alpha test will be open from Friday morning through Sunday night.  Once the client reaches a more stable version and does not require many updates, it will be open full-time.All other perks will be handed out as the game reaches a stage where they are supported, and will be automatically credited to an account created with the Alpha test key.  (Premium currency, for example, isn’t used until the game gets closer to Beta and the Premium Store opens.)What makes a Guardian ‘Common’, ‘Uncommon’, or ‘Rare’?Guardians of Noterra uses a region-based system for Guardian distribution.  Guardians found in the country of Cailatia may be very different from those found in Hondaco.  In order to somewhat preserve the different metagames for each region, a rarity system is devised, indicating how hard they are to find and import into the region.Due to the plague spread by invading monsters, each region has differing import restrictions in order to avoid cross contamination.Common:  Common Guardians are frequent in the region.  They can easily be found in the wild and it is trivial to import Guardians from the same family that appear in other regions.Uncommon:  Uncommon Guardians appear infrequently in the region.  While they can be found in the wild, it is much less likely.  Importing Uncommon Guardians is not very difficult.Rare:  The 'Rare' category covers Guardians that are not native to the region. They do not appear in the wild anywhere in the region and the import restrictions on Rare Guardians is quite steep.  Rare Guardians are not necessarily more powerful - it just means they cannot be found in that region normally.  A Guardian that is Rare to the Hondaco Region may be Common in the Cailatia region, and vice-versa.The rarities play a part in Region-based tournament modes.  Participants in high level tournaments bring up to 5 Guardians to a battle, but at most 1 of these may be Rare.  This allows participants to master the metagame within a specific region with only a few 'wild cards'.  Worldwide events allow Guardians from all over the world and do not have this restriction.
Microtransactions?  You mean this game will be Pay-to-Win?We despise games that are designed to be Pay-to-Win, and will be doing everything we can to avoid that outcome.  We plan to offer cosmetic and feature perks on the store that do not significantly affect gameplay.  We may offer Uncommon and Rare Guardians as well with the understanding that these Guardians are not necessarily more powerful than Common Guardians, just harder to get (and thus it is a time-saving feature).Anything in the Cash Store that has a gameplay benefit will be obtainable in-game in some way - such as through Tournament prizes or promotional events.  Additionally, we plan to make the Cash Store currency tradeable so that players can exchange in-game currency for Cash Store currency.  Thus, all the features are available in some way, free to play.A Message from the Lead Developer;
Hello, my name is Justin White.  I am the Sole Proprietor of Aquamentos Games and the Lead Developer of Guardians of Noterra.  I started this project because it was a game that I wanted to play.  That’s the driving passion behind Aquamentos Games – to make games that I want to play, and that I think others would like to play too.  This approach allows me to design games that are focused on gameplay – because that’s what I care about as a gamer. I’m not in this business for the money, I consider that a secondary concern.  That said, designing and running online games costs money.  The servers have to stay up, and having cash flow means more and better games in the future.  For this reason, the game will be supported with microtransactions for in-game content.  I hope that you will find the system that I intend to implement fair, without feeling like you are ‘forced’ to pay in order to enjoy the game, unlike many other games out there that use this “Freemium” (Free, with paid premiums) model.

story:
Turbo 80 is a third-person fast-paced team-based true-3D vehicular combat game set in a retro-futuristic world which perfectly captures the vibe of the 80s action and sci-fi movies. It is designed primarily for Windows systems with a very high chance for future ports on Linux, Mac, PS4 and XBOX One.

 

Turbo 80 puts you in control of a specially designed flying vehicle which has different types of weapons mounted on it. There are four general classes of vehicles in the game, each encouraging a different play style:

  • The Traveller – Really fast, has weak firepower, can be very easy to destroy
  • The Destroyer – Moderately fast, has strong ranged firepower, can be moderately easy to destroy
  • The Shielder – Very slow, strong in close combat, very hard to destroy
  • The Ressurecter – Moderately fast, can repair other vehicles in multiple ways, can be moderately hard to destroy

The combat system features two teams consisting of six players each with various vehicle types fighting for multiple points of interest on the map. The prototype of Turbo 80 contains only one implemented single player game mode in which the goal of the players is to capture multiple volumes of space scattered around the map by flying within them for 10 seconds in total. The first team to capture all the control points wins the round.

 

The levels in Turbo 80 can be generated completely procedurally, although we are currently using a hybrid method to make them more functional. We have a specially designed algorithm for generating cities that have various building types which can adapt to a procedurally generated terrain. Within the city we are able to produce flying vehicle traffic that is programmed to follow special rules of the so-called “true-3D space”.

 

The physics in Turbo 80 are custom-made fully kinematic which allow for a more arcade-style type of gameplay predominant in 80s games.

The prototype of Turbo 80 has an AI system written from scratch, and is able to navigate in non-planar 3D space (unrestricted up-down forward-backward left-right movement) which makes it distinctive from similar games in the genre. It has 100 levels of difficulty that you can choose from – the lowest being almost passive and the hardest being impossible to beat.

 

In the year 2080 flying cars were invented. The army wasted no time and turned them into combative machines. The cars played a crucial role in ending The War on Terror, but soon after the great nations of the world attacked each other, each thinking they had the superior technology. While the war was waging the terrorists were left unnoticed and gained power. Soon after, they attacked the great nations of the world from within and many of the world leaders were killed. Panic broke out and the world was separated into four Factions and a neutral zone.

The Radical Ecologists are seeking to undo the pollution that was caused by the manufacturing of the flying cars. They have developed a specialized car called The Resurrecter, which is used as a portable vehicle repair station and causes no pollution.

The Spacefarers are exhausting all resources to achieve near light speeds. They have managed to implement fast afterburners on their cars creating The Traveller. They don't believe in saving the planet and that's why they are looking to the stars for an answer.

The Traders are mainly collaborating between themselves in order to preserve their riches. They are often seen raiding other factions. The Traders resell their stolen possessions for higher prices. To help them on their raids and assert as much dominance as possible, they have developed the most powerful weapons which they mounted on their Destroyers.

The Protectors were formed with the goal of unifying the world. They were spreading peace until their ego got to them. Then they started creating heavy flying cars armed with shields and weapons. The Protectors gradually entered the combat. There are internal problems within the faction about its future. Their specialized car is called The Shielder.

 

Turbo 80’s graphics are inspired by 1980s action and sci-fi movies like some of John Carpenter’s stuff, the original Tron movie, Blade Runner, Back to the Future, Mad Max,  the series Knight Rider. We even took inspiration from some of the early works of Stanley Kubrick and some newer stuff that we saw fitting like the original Ghost in The Shell and Lost In Translation.

 

 

 

The soundtrack for the game is created by the artist known as Detective Spooks. It is a mixture of 80s synth-pop, new wave, synthwave, retrowave and other genres originating in the 80s. Currently the OST has 12 tracks. You can listen to a demo on SoundCloud.

 

Martin Petkovski – programming, art direction, rigging, animation, music, sound effects, level design

Stefan Kuzmanovski – 3D graphics, art direction, level design, texturing, animation, rigging

Jovan Jovanovski – Story writer

Turbo 80 is currently a fully functional prototype, the core mechanics are complete. It has four playable classes, each one has different abilities and playstyles.

March 2017 – Development started with creating concept art and designing the core gameplay elements.

April 2017 – Active development started – Most of the content was added, the core gameplay was functional.

May 2017 – Working prototype – Others were testing the game, improvements were made to the gameplay, more content was added.

June 2017 – The story was written. More content was added.

July 2017 – The Indiegogo campaign started.

~ Q2 2018 – Early access with multiplayer options*

~Q4 2018 – Port to other platforms*

*depends on funds collected

  • Finishing the game regardless of funds collected
  • Implementing multiplayer modes
  • Adding additional environments
  • Improvements on the procedural world generation, adding more transit systems, light pollution with billboards and vegetation
  • Real-time synthetized sound effects
  • Rigs and animations
  • Improving particle systems
  • Reaching 20 tracks on the soundtrack
  • More game modes
  • Additional cars for each class
  • Implementing different aspects of the story in the gameplay. During the single player the users will choose to ally themselves with one out of the four different factions: The Traders, The Protectors, The Radical Ecologists and The Spacefarers. In addition, with the faction they align themselves with, the players will receive a specially modified car which is exquisite to that faction. Depending on the faction, the player will have to complete specified tasks that benefit the faction and thus will get at least a foundation of the game before going into the multiplayer. The multiplayer takes place in Africa or The Neutral Zone, where fully automated cities are left for the players to raid.

 

So far this project was created in our free time with no direct funding, and that slowed down the creative process a lot. The sole reason we chose flexible funding is that we intend on finishing the game regardless of funds collected. The funds may only free us of daily obligations and speed up the development progress.

 

Get in touch:

Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/turboeighty/

Twitter - https://twitter.com/returnthatzero

YouTube - https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCkmc-yEqipfFC4OEEcgC7bg

Email - returnthatzero@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

B’Bop and Friends was created to inspire and encourage African American youth and children to pursue careers in Technology and become creators and developers,

It's important for African-American children to see themselves and read stories about themselves and their culture in books, film and yes, now in Video Games. We have to meet our children where they are, and they play a lot of Video Games. We need to make sure they are seeing themselves portrayed accurately.  B'Bop and Friends 3D World is a positive representation for African American families and children.

The development and enhancements to the Game will be managed by Gre-Fonda Hardy, CEO of B’Bop and Friends, and Noelle Hardy, Vice-President.  Creators and developers are Michael Sanders, Concept Artist, Chijioke Okereke, 3D Modeler, Raven Robinson, Fashion Designer, Joshua Jones, Game Designer and Chris Washington, Game Designer.  More developers, such as the 3D Character Animators, Game Programmers and Game Graphic Artist will be added to the team as we move along in the development phase of the project.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $357,000 for further development of B'Bop and Friends 3D World. During this project we will develop Game and App Tech skills by providing employment opportunities, internships and mentoring to minorities interested in Game and App Development.  The details are listed below.

    •     We will expand the Basketball Game and create a Michigan High School
          Championship Basketball Game for the two final teams.  New live action
          NCAA style of play will be created and applied to the basketball players such
          as powerful dunking, blocking, guarding, all the phenomenal plays you see in
          the NCAA.  Players will be able to play the game and compete
          from anywhere in the world on the Internet.  Of course we can't upgrade to
          this level of play without creating a 3D College level Basketball Arena with
          people in the stands, coaches, referees and cheerleaders for the Michigan High
          School Championship Finals.  Customers will have the choice to purchase the
          newly enhanced Basketball Game individually or a smaller version of the
          enhanced Basketball game bundled in the B'Bop and Friends 3D B'Bop and
          Friends 3D World.  

    •     To add more interactivity in the 3D Bedrooms for each character, we have
          hired a Fashion Designer from New York, to design new original clothing for
          each character. That's right the characters will have a fly wardrobe with
          different hair styles to match that can be exchanged, replaced or removed.  At
          night, put the characters to sleep and wake the characters up at any specified
          time.  The characters will continue to perform the animations they currently
          perform now with a few enhancements.
       
    •     To add more interactivity to the Tennis Game we will add 3D Environments for
          the winning players can select to visit after they finish their Tennis match. 
      1. US Open in New York City.  Times Square and Statue of Liberty.
      2. French Open in Paris France. Eiffel Tower.
      3. Wimbledon in London, UK.
      4. We will add a referee and people in the stands with animation in the Tennis Game.
    •     The 3D Neighborhood scene will be developed.  It will be completely
          interactive giving the player the ability to build homes for each character, a
          school and a shopping Mall.
       
    •     The 3D Skateboard Scene will become interactivity and competitive.  Hop,
          B'Bop and another character extra will compete in the Skateboard Competition
          Finals.  
       
    •     The Dance Studio will also get an upgrade.  We want to create a Hip Hop
          Dance Crew with Noe and 3 new characters.  Character Noe and her crew will
          be able to change Dancing outfit's depending on their Dance schedule which
          could be rehearsals, recitals or dance classes.         

The Impact

There's a big hole in the Gaming Industry that needs to be filled.  Missing are African-Americans.  With a successful Game Development business, B'Bop and Friends will be able to develop and provide Tech employment opportunities to minorities, start an internship and mentoring program for minorities who dream of becoming Game and App Developers and Creators.  B'Bop and Friends is positioned to interrupt the cycle of non-inclusion in this multi billion dollar industry.
 
Children need to see that it's possible and obtainable for African-American's to use their imagination and Technology to develop solutions that solve problems and change the world.  Children need to see African-American's in the profession's they are being encouraged to pursue.  We also need to be in a position to assist minorities with developing their Tech skills.

I started a gaming business because of the interest African-American children have in games.  I know that we can reach them here and that's my goal and my mission to help our children become developers and creators, not just users and buyers of Tech. They need to have an interest, but it's up to us to give them the exposure and opportunities to develop those interest. 

 A young Concept Artist who attends College of Creative Studies in Detroit has joined our team and will be creating the Concept Art for the new characters we will be using in the next release of the game,  After seeing the work the Concept Artist is doing, 16 and 15 year old Gamer's became very interested in Game Development and asked if they can work with us to create games.  After watching them play the B'Bop and Friends Basketball Game which they figured out on their own and the feedback they provided, I knew right away I needed them to be on the Game Design team.  I decided to bring them on as B'Bop and Friends Interns to help design and test the new enhancements for this project.  They are very smart and learn very quickly.  They are very happy and very excited to have this once in a life time opportunity to intern at a Game Development Company and be on a Game Design team at 16 and 15 years old.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially that doesn't mean you can't help.   Please help us get the word out and share the information about the Campaign that can be a game changer for many minority children and youth.  We need your support so whatever you can do will be greatly appreciated.  

Sincerely,
Gre-Fonda Hardy, CEO
B'Bop and Friends, LLC.
story_txt:
Short Summary
B’Bop and Friends was created to inspire and encourage African American youth and children to pursue careers in Technology and become creators and developers,
It's important for African-American children to see themselves and read stories about themselves and their culture in books, film and yes, now in Video Games. We have to meet our children where they are, and they play a lot of Video Games. We need to make sure they are seeing themselves portrayed accurately.  B'Bop and Friends 3D World is a positive representation for African American families and children.
The development and enhancements to the Game will be managed by Gre-Fonda Hardy, CEO of B’Bop and Friends, and Noelle Hardy, Vice-President.  Creators and developers are Michael Sanders, Concept Artist, Chijioke Okereke, 3D Modeler, Raven Robinson, Fashion Designer, Joshua Jones, Game Designer and Chris Washington, Game Designer.  More developers, such as the 3D Character Animators, Game Programmers and Game Graphic Artist will be added to the team as we move along in the development phase of the project.

What We Need & What You Get
We need $357,000 for further development of B'Bop and Friends 3D World. During this project we will develop Game and App Tech skills by providing employment opportunities, internships and mentoring to minorities interested in Game and App Development.  The details are listed below.
    We will expand the Basketball Game and create a Michigan High School    Championship Basketball Game for the two final teams.  New live action    NCAA style of play will be created and applied to the basketball players such    as powerful dunking, blocking, guarding, all the phenomenal plays you see in    the NCAA.  Players will be able to play the game and compete    from anywhere in the world on the Internet.  Of course we can't upgrade to    this level of play without creating a 3D College level Basketball Arena with    people in the stands, coaches, referees and cheerleaders for the Michigan High    School Championship Finals.  Customers will have the choice to purchase the    newly enhanced Basketball Game individually or a smaller version of the    enhanced Basketball game bundled in the B'Bop and Friends 3D B'Bop and    Friends 3D World.  
    To add more interactivity in the 3D Bedrooms for each character, we have    hired a Fashion Designer from New York, to design new original clothing for    each character. That's right the characters will have a fly wardrobe with    different hair styles to match that can be exchanged, replaced or removed.  At    night, put the characters to sleep and wake the characters up at any specified    time.  The characters will continue to perform the animations they currently    perform now with a few enhancements. 
    To add more interactivity to the Tennis Game we will add 3D Environments for    the winning players can select to visit after they finish their Tennis match. 
US Open in New York City.  Times Square and Statue of Liberty.
French Open in Paris France. Eiffel Tower.
Wimbledon in London, UK.
We will add a referee and people in the stands with animation in the Tennis Game.


    The 3D Neighborhood scene will be developed.  It will be completely    interactive giving the player the ability to build homes for each character, a    school and a shopping Mall. 
    The 3D Skateboard Scene will become interactivity and competitive.  Hop,    B'Bop and another character extra will compete in the Skateboard Competition    Finals.   
    The Dance Studio will also get an upgrade.  We want to create a Hip Hop    Dance Crew with Noe and 3 new characters.  Character Noe and her crew will    be able to change Dancing outfit's depending on their Dance schedule which    could be rehearsals, recitals or dance classes.         



The Impact
There's a big hole in the Gaming Industry that needs to be filled.  Missing are African-Americans.  With a successful Game Development business, B'Bop and Friends will be able to develop and provide Tech employment opportunities to minorities, start an internship and mentoring program for minorities who dream of becoming Game and App Developers and Creators.  B'Bop and Friends is positioned to interrupt the cycle of non-inclusion in this multi billion dollar industry. Children need to see that it's possible and obtainable for African-American's to use their imagination and Technology to develop solutions that solve problems and change the world.  Children need to see African-American's in the profession's they are being encouraged to pursue.  We also need to be in a position to assist minorities with developing their Tech skills.
I started a gaming business because of the interest African-American children have in games.  I know that we can reach them here and that's my goal and my mission to help our children become developers and creators, not just users and buyers of Tech. They need to have an interest, but it's up to us to give them the exposure and opportunities to develop those interest. 
 A young Concept Artist who attends College of Creative Studies in Detroit has joined our team and will be creating the Concept Art for the new characters we will be using in the next release of the game,  After seeing the work the Concept Artist is doing, 16 and 15 year old Gamer's became very interested in Game Development and asked if they can work with us to create games.  After watching them play the B'Bop and Friends Basketball Game which they figured out on their own and the feedback they provided, I knew right away I needed them to be on the Game Design team.  I decided to bring them on as B'Bop and Friends Interns to help design and test the new enhancements for this project.  They are very smart and learn very quickly.  They are very happy and very excited to have this once in a life time opportunity to intern at a Game Development Company and be on a Game Design team at 16 and 15 years old.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute financially that doesn't mean you can't help.   Please help us get the word out and share the information about the Campaign that can be a game changer for many minority children and youth.  We need your support so whatever you can do will be greatly appreciated.  
Sincerely,Gre-Fonda Hardy, CEOB'Bop and Friends, LLC.

story:
Have you ever get goosebumps thinking about Windows 95?
Do you imagine a perfect friday night with a glass of wine, while your old pc softly plays some 8-bit game soundtrack at the background?

Well..

Glitch Warz is a modern flashback of what a great fight looked like back in the 90's.
Except that possibilities are unlimited here: the maps are randomly generated and all of them gives you the feel of the nostalgic atmosphere.

This game would’ve destroyed more friendships in the 90's than accidentally overwritten VHS tapes.

 

How would you lead your team to fight if you only had one soldier?
Are you willing to use violence? Of course, that's your only chance, negotiation is for the weak!

A great victory has nothing to do with luck anymore. It requires perfect timing, clean shots, forecast skills, and exact mathematical calculations.

If your tactic is not good enough for victory surprise them with tricky shots, and end the game unexpectedly using glitches like: unique rockets, heals and shields.

 

Don’t let your device preferences stand in your way. Play Glitch Warz across platforms like iOS, Android or your desktop browser.

 

Wanna go multiplayer with your friend? No problem! Share one phone and take turns or connect to the same wifi network and start a battle together.

 

"Whenever you are confronted with an opponent. Conquer him with Glitches" /Gandhi/


May the best win (or the tricky one)!
